ef649cf2-e58e-4bb7-8c4c-54e1a6d5f95b.description: Earners of this badge understand the core principles behind Reactive Architecture and the Reactive Manifesto. Earners know why a Reactive System is needed, and what problems it solves. Earners understand the differences between Reactive Architecture and Systems vs Reactive Programming.
ef649cf2-e58e-4bb7-8c4c-54e1a6d5f95b.name: Reactive Architecture: Introduction to Reactive Systems - Level 2

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the Reactive Architecture: Introduction to Reactive Systems

Receive a passing grade in the assessed portions of the course.

5f3d71d7-96c2-4037-89d8-2dcfc3ecbcc6.description: Earners of this badge understand the core principles behind Domain Driven Design, and how it applies to Reactive Architecture. They understand how to partition a domain into bounded contexts, how to extract aggregate roots, and how to form microservices around those aggregate roots. They understand the relationship between command and events, entities and value objects, and factories and repositories.
5f3d71d7-96c2-4037-89d8-2dcfc3ecbcc6.name: Reactive Architecture: Domain Driven Design - Level 2

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the Reactive Architecture: Domain Driven Design course.

Receive a passing grade in the assessed portions of the course.

c5f691db-791b-4db0-8c08-f54ba2cd2d6b.description: Earners of this badge understand the difference between a monolithic system, and a microservices system. They recognize the value of introducing isolation into their application to improve stability, maintainability, and scalability. They understand some of the techniques used to introduce isolation such as bulkheading, autonomy, and asynchronous messaging.
c5f691db-791b-4db0-8c08-f54ba2cd2d6b.name: Reactive Architecture: Reactive Microservices - Level 2

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the Reactive Architecture: Reactive Microservices course

Receive a passing grade in the assessed portions of the course.

fca8ba71-22b8-457e-b42a-bc8d84f8ab4b.description: Earners of this badge can program basic to intermediate production applications using the fundamentals of the Scala programming language. Earners can code using Scala OO basics such as classes, class parameters, fields, default arguments, methods, packages and Scala Case Classes. Earners understand Scala code testing. Earners can code Scala Collections and Functional basics, For Loops, For Expressions, Inheritance and Traits, Scala Pattern Matching, Option Values and Try.

b2e13cfd-27e2-4f22-afee-4165922a9545.description: Earners of this badge understand key concepts in building distributed systems. They recognize the limitations imposed by a network. They know how Amdahl's law and Gunther's Universal Scalability Law limit scalability. They recognize the importance of the CAP theorem. They have also learned about techniques to balance these concerns such as sharding and Conflict-Free Replicated Data Types.
b2e13cfd-27e2-4f22-afee-4165922a9545.name: Reactive Architecture: Building Scalable Systems - Level 2

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the Reactive Architecture: Building Scalable Systems course.

Receive a passing grade in the assessed portions of the course.

db0a7cec-1d74-4457-992d-b14ec479889a.description: Earners of this badge understand some of the patterns that can be applied in distributed systems. They recognize the difference between synchronous and asynchronous messages, and the tradeoffs between them. They know how to apply point-to-point messaging along with publish-subscribe messaging. Critically, they understand messaging guarantees, such as at-most-once, at-least-once, and effectively-once.
db0a7cec-1d74-4457-992d-b14ec479889a.name: Reactive Architecture: Distributed Messaging Patterns - Level 2

badge_template_activities.title: Complete the Reactive Architecture: Distributed Messaging Patterns course.

f931407e-1d24-462e-8053-b3ae31a5a500.description: Earners of this badge understand the relationship between CQRS and Event Sourcing. They recognize the important role that these techniques can play in building highly scalable, distributed systems. They have learned the value of building systems that have built in auditability. They can recognize how separating reads and writes can allow systems more flexibility in how they provide both consistency, and scalability.
f931407e-1d24-462e-8053-b3ae31a5a500.name: Reactive Architecture: CQRS and Event Sourcing - Level 2

c7c20cdc-debf-4db5-a4d8-13ff0ddf31b2.description: Earners of this badge can design, program and configure highly scalable, stable, efficient and reactive Akka Clusters. Akka Clusters scale in ways not possible using traditional architectures. Earners understand Akka Cluster principles, topology, cluster formation and communication. Earners can configure and use cluster management and logging, and can diagnose failures including cluster split brain scenarios. Earners can heal clusters by configuring and running Lightbend Split Brain Resolver.

Earners can configure, test, and tune Akka. Earners know the best practices for designing asynchronous, event-driven systems using Akka. Earners can code an Akka Actor, message communication to/from an Actor, Actor state, and scheduling Actors. Earners understand Akka Actor lifecycle, and can code and configure fault tolerance, and routers and dispatchers.

690f0fc4-7a00-4dba-9cf5-523cb1ea86de.description: Earners of this badge can write Java code using Java CompletableFutures. CompletableFutures allow us to create asynchronous, non-blocking operations, which are an important part of building Reactive systems. Earners understand blocking operations, and how they impact the efficiency of a system. Earners can use CompletableFutures to isolate blocking operations, and and transform those futures over time. Earners can use Executors to control the threadpool that is used to execute a future.
